Award.AbstractNarration:
Hyperbolic conservation laws are a class of mathematical equations describing a wide variety of phenomena, including gas dynamics, water waves, liquid crystals, and vehicle flow. Their study dates back to Euler (1755). However, several theoretical problems remain unresolved to this day. The presence of discontinuities in the solutions, in the form of shock waves, is a major source of difficulties in the analysis of these equations. The present research will seek advances in the understanding of solutions with large data, and error propagation in case when, as it happens in real-life situations, the initial conditions are not known with absolute precision. In addition, a major portion of the research will focus on conservation laws describing traffic flow on a network of roads. New models for vehicle flow at road intersections will be developed, which are realistic and easily computable. In particular, these models will account for the possible spill-back of queues along roads leading to a congested intersection. At a second stage, the PI will study traffic patterns arising as
(i) global optima, where departures are scheduled by a central planner in order to minimize a global cost to all drivers, and
(ii) Nash equilibria, where each driver selects a departure time and a route to destination, in order to minimize his/her own individual cost.
In connection with recent technological advances in the collection of traffic data and the automatic driving of cars, developing efficient mathematical models will provide an important step toward the prediction and the optimal control of traffic flow.

The first part of the research aims at fundamental advances in the theory of conservation laws and nonlinear wave equations. In particular, building upon recent progress, the PI will study the global existence of solutions with large total variation and the appearance of vacuum in finite time, for isentropic gas dynamics. The research will rely on a number of new approaches.
(i) In the study of gas dynamics, a priori estimates or examples of blow-up will first be studied within certain classes of approximate solutions, which are easier to describe and that capture the essential features of true solutions.
(ii) In the analysis of error estimates, geodesic distances will be used, whenever the standard Sobolev norms do not yield useful information.
In some interesting cases, the specific form of these metrics is motivated by optimal transportation problems.
(iii) For the new models of traffic flow at a junction of roads, a solution will be constructed as the fixed point of a contractive transformation, defined by a novel version of the Lax formula.
The PI serves as Director of a new Center for Interdisciplinary Mathematics at Penn State. Its primary goal is to foster scientific interactions, widening the use and appreciation of modern mathematical techniques as effective research tools in a variety of disciplines. Some of the topics of the present proposal, such as traffic flow models, are naturally interdisciplinary and will be included in the activities of the Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theoretical part of this project was mainly focused on nonlinear wave equations. A distinguished feature of these equations is that solutions are not smooth, but develop singularities.  Indeed, the graph of these functions can have jumps, cusps, or kinks.   Much of the difficulty encountered in the analysis and in the numerical solution of these equations stems from this lack of regularity. 
This project has provided a better understanding of these singularities. More specifically, it was found that, for various classes of wave equations, almost all solutions remain smooth outside at a finite number of curves in space-time,  Along these curves, the graph has a vertical tangent. A detailed classification of singular points was achieved, together with a description of  the local behavior of the solution near these points. The results apply in particular to the so-called "variational wave equation" arising from a model of liquid crystals.

A second part of the research dealt with applications of hyperbolic conservation lawsto the modeling of traffic flow on a networks of roads.        As we all have experienced, a most relevant feature of traffic flow are the traffic jams.These occur whenever too many people choose to drive on the same road at the same time. One can thus view a traffic pattern as the outcome of the decisions made by very many drivers, who choose their departure times and  routes to destination trying to minimize their own cost. Here the travel cost may include the time spent on the road and a penalty for late arrival.

Toward an understanding of these traffic patterns, the research project has achieved two main goals.
First, a new model for traffic flow at road intersections has been introduced.This is ``well posed", in the sense that it predicts a unique solution, nicely depending on the observed initial data.  Moreover, it captures essential features of traffic flow, such as  the backward propagation of queues along roads leading to a crowded intersection. Relations between the new intersection model and earlier ones considered in the literature have  also been clarified.
Next, relying on this new model, the PI has studied the corresponding optimal decision problem. Globally optimal solutions have been obtained, where the sum of all costs to all drivers is minimized. Moreover, adopting a classical concept  of game theory, "equilibrium solutions" have also been constructed.  These are traffic patterns where the decision made by each driver (concerning his/her departure time and route to destination) is best possible, subject to the traffic conditions determined by all other drivers. This yields a more realistic description of daily traffic.

This project provided training for 5 graduate students and 5 postdocs. Nearly all of the 20 publications stemming from this project were written by the PI jointly with young researchers. Some of them have already obtained tenure-track positions at US academic institutions, while others are still completing their training at Penn State.
As a side activity, the PI has been one of the main organizers of the 17-th Conference on Hyperbolic Problems: Theory, Numerics, and Applications,  held at Penn State on June 25--29, 2018.  Conferences of this kind take place every other year, and have become established as the world's foremost venue for research on compressible fluid flow and wave equations.The recent meeting had 232  registered  participants, and a large number of talks were given by junior researchers, including several Ph.D. students and postdocs from American universities.
